Name: DDE
Description: DDE is a chlorophenylethylene that is ethylene substituted by two 4-chlorophenyl groups at position 1 and two chlorine atoms at position 2. It has a role as a persistent organic pollutant and a human xenobiotic metabolite. It is a member of monochlorobenzenes and a chlorophenylethylene.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Bacci E et al; Chemosphere 17: 693-702 (1988) (2) Tremolada P et al; Chemosphere 27: 2235-52 (1993) (3) Mahugijarco JA et al; Chemosphere 61: 1293-8 (2005) (4) Barriada-Pereira M et al; Chemosphere 58: 1571-8 (2005) (5) Borghini F et al; Chemosphere 58: 271-8 (2005) (6) Abbassy MS et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 70: 1158-64 (2003)
plant_concentrations.Value: DDE was detected in mango leaves collected from 5 countries in western Africa at concns of 0.2-39 ng/g(1). DDE was detected in mango leaves collected in various locations of Africa at concns of 0.1-36 ng/g(2). In Vikuge farm in Tanzania, mean concentrations (ng/g fw) of p,p-DDE and o,p-DDE were detected in C. exaltatus roots (328.9, 192.1 ng/g), leaves (114.6, 42.0 ng/g), and leaves from 6 km north (1.1, 0.3 ng/g); P. maximum fresh leaves from 30 m north (3.0, 1.1 ng/g), fresh leaves from 100 m west (3.4, 1.1 ng/g), and dried hay (72.4, 26.1 ng/g); and P. purpureum leaves from 60 m north (0.9, 0.6 ng/g) and stems from 60 m north (6.9, 2.4 ng/g)(3). DDE was detected (LOD = 0.003 mg/kg) in 5 different species of plants collected from Galicia, Spain at concn ranges of: <LOD to 0.080 (Cytisus striatus), <LOD to 0.164 (Avena sativa), <LOD to 0.098 (Vivia sativa), <LOD to 0.274 (Solanum nigra), and <LOD to 0.195 (Chenopodium vulgare)(4). In 1999, 4,4'-DDE was detected in mosses from Antarctica at concn range of 1.1-7.9 ng/g dry weight(5). During 1997-1998, DDE was detected in 100% of 3 aquatic plant species samples collected from Lake Manzala, Egypt at mean, min and max concns of, respectively, 5.65, 4.11, 7.01 ng/g (hechrish), 5.09, 3.71, 6.43 ng/g (adas), 2.96, 2.45, 3.43 ng/g wet weight (amshout)(6).

plant_concentrations.References: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY. 2001, p. 644
plant_concentrations.Value: In aquatic vascular plants in Lake Paijanne, Finland: mean: 2 ug/kg dry weight (1972-1973).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Frank R et al; Arch Environ Contam 12: 641-54 (1983) (2) Reichel WL et al; Environ Monit Assess 4: 395-403 (1984) (3) McEwen LC et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 3: 367-76 (1984) (4) Paasivirta J et al; Chemosphere 14: 457-68 (1985) (5) Albanis TA et al; Sci Total Environ 182: 11-19 (1996) (6) Albert LA; pp. 1-44 in Rev. Environ Contam Toxicol. Vol. 147. Ware GW, ed. NY, NY: Springer-Verlag (1996) (7) Anthony RG et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 26: 1843-55 (2007) (8) Desolla SR et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 7252-9 (2007) (9) Custer TW et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 40: 87-100 (2001) (10) Jaspers V et al; Environ Pollut 136: 81-8 (2005) (11) Abbassy MS et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 70: 1158-64 (2003) (12) Fangstrom B et al; Chemosphere 60: 836-43 (2005)
animal_concentrations.Value: DDE was detected in eggs of common loons in Ontario, Canada from 1968-1980 at avg concns of 3.98-41.4 ppm (wet wt)(1). DDE was detected in 293 out of 293 dead or moribund bald eagle carcass' in the US from 1978-1981 at median concns of 2.5 ppm (1978), 2.4 ppm (1979), 3.3 ppm(1980) and 3.0 ppm (1981)(2). DDE was detected in 147 out of 147 black-capped night-heron eggs in Colorado and Wyoming (1979) at concns of 0.33-44 ppm(3). DDE was detected in starlings from Finland from 1967-1983 at avg concns of 517-7,522 ppb(4). DDE was detected in heron nestlings and frogs in the Thermaikos Gulf, Greece at concns of 0-12.65 ug/kg and 0-0.64 ug/kg, respectively(5). Mean DDE concns of 0.02-11.46 ug/g were reported for various birds from 3 agricultural valleys in northwest Mexico(6). Geometric mean concns (ranges) of DDE in 136 bald eagle eggs collected from 2000-2004 in 8 different islands in the Aleutian archipelago, Alaska, were 1.239 (0.449-2.794), 0.848 (0.447-6.66), 0.679 (0.246-2.3), 0.673 (0.228-1.917), 0.576 (0.274-1.011), 0.534 (0.355-0.99), 0.755 (0.288-2.56), and 0.602 (0.221-1.38) ug/g wet weight(7). The mean concns of DDE in snapping turtle eggs collected from different sites along Lake Ontario, the St. Lawrence River, and connecting channels from 2001-2004, ranged from 3.75 to 152 ng/g wet weight(8). Double-crested cormorant chicks collected from two colonies in Green Bay, WI, accumulated on average 7-12 ug/day of DDE, compared to 1 ug/day at 2 reference colonies in SD and MN(9). DDE was detected in egg samples of little owls from Belgium between 1998 and 2000 at a median concn of 830 ng/g lipid(10). During 1997-1998, DDE was detected in 100% of 3 bird species muscle samples from Lake Manzala, Egypt, at mean, min and max concns of, respectively, 210.9, 65.4, 291.7 ng/g (moorhen), 14.57, 6.51, 24.52 ng/g (kingfisher), 442.5, 163.8, 721.3 ng/g wet weight (cattle egret)(11). Fulmar samples collected in 2000-2001 from the Faroe Islands in the North Atlantic, detected mean (range) concentrations (ng/g lipid weight) of DDE in Fulmar egg, adult muscle, juvenile muscle, and juvenile subcutaneous fat of 2800 (1,000-7,000), 7100 (1,700-20,000), 530 (260-1,800), and 610 (230-2,000), respectively(12).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Oshea TJ et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 40: 112-120 (2001) (2) Bennett BS, Thies ML; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 78: 191-4 (2007) (3) Vetter W et al; Environ Sci Technol 37: 840-4 (2003) (4) Kunisue T et al; Chemosphere 66: 203-11 (2007) (5) Fellers GM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 23: 2170-7 (2004)
animal_concentrations.Value: DDE was detected in guano of big brown bats, collected in the summers of 1997-1998 from 2 maternity roosts near the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Area (RMA), CO, at mean (range) concn of 0.08 (not detected-0.26) and 0.07 (0.02-0.31) ug/g air dry weight from 2 different buildings, respectively; two reference roosts approx 80 km away at Fort Collins, CO, both had a mean concn of 0.02 ug/g and ranges of not detected to 0.04 ug/g(1). DDE was detected in the carcasses of big brown bats at RMA in the following sexes, at geometric mean (max) concentrations in ug/g wet weight: males, 1.2 (16); females, 0.25 (2.9); juveniles, 1.1 (3.3); in a maternity roost: juveniles, 0.96 (1.04); at Fort Collins reference location: males, 0.34 (0.63); females, 0.08 (0.58); juveniles, 0.59 (1.60)(1). DDE was detected in brains of big brown bats at RMA in the following sexes, at geometric mean (ranges) concentrations in ug/g wet weight: males, 0.23 (0.11-1.6); females, 0.1 (0.10-1.4); juveniles, 0.15 (0.10-0.67); in a maternity roost: juveniles, 0.24 (not detected-0.45); at Fort Collins reference location: males, 0.07 (0.11-0.17); females, 0.08 (0.10-0.27); juveniles, 0.09 (0.10-0.23)(1). From 1998 to 1999, DDE was detected in all Brazilian Free-tailed bat guano and dermestid beetle samples collected from East Texas, with concns ranging between 0.001-0.015 ug/g and 0.001-0.006 ug/g, respectively(2). DDE was detected in the blubber of an Antarctic Weddell seal at a concn of 8.8 ug/kg wet weight(3). In 2001, the mean concn (in ng/g lipid weight) of p,p'-DDE detected in the liver and muscle of racoon dogs from Japan was 58 (range of 5.3-150) and 24 (range of 2.0-59), respectively(4). DDE was detected in tissue from mountain yellow-legged frogs (Rana muscosa) in August 1997 from Sequoia National Park and Kings Canyon National Park, CA, at mean (median) concns of 45.69 (46.72) and 16.96 (19.34) ng/g wet weight, respectively(5).

animal_concentrations.References: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY. 2001, p. 644
animal_concentrations.Value: Mean residues in eggs of American crocodile in Everglades National Park: 1.8 ppm wet weight (1972), 1.2 ppm wet weight (1977-1978); seal, Baltic Sea, blubber: 138 mg/g; Alaskan seal, Alaska, fat: 0.110 mg/g; sea duck, Alaska, fat: 0.17 mg/g

Specimens were taken of the gills, brains, liver, muscle, fat, gonads, and intestinal contents of 35 asps, 3 pike perches, and 3 breams. A total of 7 pesticides were detected. The highest concentrations found were those of DDE, followed by lindane. Females exhibited higher rates of accumulation due to their higher rates of lipid turnover, growth, and feeding. Predators such as the asp and the pike perch contained higher concentrations than did non-predator species.

animal_concentrations.References: Olsen P et al; Aust Wildl Res 7 (1): 139-47 (1980)
animal_concentrations.Value: Studies were performed to determine general environmental organochlorine contamination by examining the wings of ducks in southeast Australia. Organochlorine levels in wings were compared to other body parts. Tissues from 12 species collected at 10 sites were analyzed for organochlorines. Wings were ground and macerated, extracted, and analyzed by gas liquid chromatography. All wings contained DDT and DDE. No organophosphates were detected. The mean concentrations for male Pacific black ducks were 42.13 ppm (wing), 2.1 ppm (brain), 10.03 (liver), 331.29 ppm (fat), and 3.43 ppm (breast muscle). Highly significant positive correlations were found between DDT residues in wings and each of the body parts examined. Similar trends were observed for birds collected at various locations. It is suggested that monitoring be conducted to follow changes in organochlorine levels and reveal possible problem areas.

The body burdens of 5 organochlorine compounds were determined in several marine fishes and invertebrates from 2 localities in Norway. DDE, PCBs, and pentachlorobenzene showed uniform levels, especially on a fat weight basis, while hexachlorobenzene, and octachlorostyrene were detected at various levels in different species. The results are discussed with respect to the concept of accumulation through food chains, and passive partition of chemicals between water and the organism's fat. Although the results to some extent support the idea of partition, other factors may have a decisive effect on the levels found in the different species. This is true for the bottom dwellers, where magnitude and circumstances of exposure may vary considerably between the different microenvironments.

animal_concentrations.References: Stone WB et al; NY Fish Game J 27 (1): 39-50 (1980)
animal_concentrations.Value: Results are reported of the analysis of organochlorine contaminants in selected tissues of 32 snapping turtles from New York waters (23 from the Hudson River and 9 from other localities). Fat, liver, skeletal muscle, and eggs were analyzed by gas chromatography. PCBs were found in all samples; the highest was found in fat of turtles from the Hudson River (mean= 2990.60 ppm). Of the 17 fat samples tested for dieldrin, 10 had high concentrations (> 0.3 ppm). Of the 16 samples tested for DDE, 5 had concentrations > 5 ppm. It is suggested that the turtles from the Hudson River and from some other localities are unfit for human consumption due to contamination with such persistent pollutants.

animal_concentrations.References: Matsumura, F. Toxicology of Insecticides. 2nd ed. New York, NY: Plenum Press, 1985., p. 468
animal_concentrations.Value: ... A comprehensive study of the distribution of p,p'-DDE and dieldrin (HEOD) in a marine environment on the eastern coast of Britain (near Farne Islands, Northumberland) /has been made/. ... Residue data /were compiled/ on 22 marine species and on micro- and macrozooplankton and plotted ... against their trophic levels. The overall picture roughly agrees with the concept of higher pesticide levels in higher trophic levels, although variation among the individual species within a trophic level was great. The variation was particularly great in trophic level 4, where several bird species (shags, ducks, gulls) are grouped together with some fish (eg, cod and whiting). Shags, in particular, showed very high dieldrin (highest) and DDE (second highest) residues, thereby contributing to the wide variation in this trophic level.

environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: BCF values of DDE have been reported in the following aquatic organisms: rainbow trout, 81,000(2); fathead minnow, 51,000(3); fish (no species reported, static microcosm study), 27,500(4); Gambusia affinis, 217 (3 days exposure)(1); trout, 1.8X10+5, bluegill sunfish, 1.1X10+5(6). According to a classification scheme(7), these BCF data suggest bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is very high(SRC). BCF values of 28,600 have been reported in zooplankton(5).

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: Callahan, M.A., M.W. Slimak, N.W. Gabel, et al. Water-Related Environmental Fate of 129 Priority Pollutants. Volume I. EPA-440/4 79-029a. Washington, DC: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, December 1979., p. 24-7
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: ... In a terrestrial-aquatic microcosm experiment on the fate of DDE ... the bioconcentration factors found were 3.6X10+4, 5.9X10+4, and 1.2X10+4 for snail, mosquito larvae, and fish; a concentration factor for algae in this experiment was 1.1X10+4. The concentration of DDE in water was 3.8 ppb.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY. 2001, p. 645
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: Bioconcentration factor in aquatic model ecosystem: alga: 2720; snail (Cipangopaludina japonica): 13700; carp (Cyprinus carpio): 8450.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: Matsumura, F. Toxicology of Insecticides. 2nd ed. New York, NY: Plenum Press, 1985., p. 469
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: For nonagricultural terrestrial areas, there is only a limited amount of information on food chain accumulations. ... DDE residue levels /have been studied/ in two species of raptors in Alaska (along the Colville River, where there is no record of DDT spray) compared to those in their prey. ... /The/ data indicate a modest biomagnification in the rough-legged hawk and a high concn factor in the peregrine falcon. ... /It was/ reasoned that while the former preys exclusively on the native species (small ground mammals), the latter feeds on both native and migrant bird species. Another explanation of the difference might be that the rough-legged hawk feeds exclusively on ground mammals and the peregrine falcon on various bird species known to be capable of accumulating DDT total residues.

environmental_bioconcentrations.References: Murty, A.S. Toxicity of Pesticides to Fish. Volumes I, II. Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press Inc., 1986., p. V2 21
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: There have been but a few studies on the alteration of pesticide toxicity in saline waters. ... /It has been/ reported that young mosquitofish accum significantly lesser amounts of DDT, DDE, and DDD in 15% saline waters than in freshwater.

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Tabak HH et al; J Water Pollut Control Fed 53: 1503-18 (1981) (2) Vind HP et al; Biodeterioration of Navy Insecticides in the Ocean. NTIS AD-77310 (1973) (3) Echelberger JW, Litchtenberg JJ; Environ Sci Technol 5: 541-4 (1971) (4) Lee RF, Ryan C; Microbial Degradation of Organochlorine Compounds in Estuarine Waters and Sediments. USEPA-600/9-79-012 (1979) (5) Subba-Rao RV, Alexander M; Agric Food Chem 25: 327-9 (1977)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: DDE was not degraded in static screening tests using settled domestic wastewater inoculum with yeast extract, with 3 additional subcultures added every 7 days(1). No degradation of DDE exposed to ocean sediments in seawater under aerobic conditions were observed after 12 months(2). No degradation of DDE observed after 8 weeks of exposure of DDE in lab tests to raw water from a stream which received domestic and industrial wastes and farm runoff(3). Half-life of DDE exposed to river sediments was 1,100 days(4). BOD after 30 days of <1.0 ug O2/mL for DDE exposed to soil inoculum indicated only slight biodegradation(5).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Vind HP et al; Biodeterioration of Navy Insecticides in the Ocean. NTIS AD-77310 (1973) (2) Boul HL; Chemosphere 32: 855-66 (1996)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: No degradation of DDE exposed to ocean sediments in seawater under anaerobic conditions were observed after 12 months(1). p,p'-DDE was less than 1% mineralized in flooded soils during a 42 day incubation period(2).

PURE CULTURE: Under aerobic conditions, the ring cleavage of DDT by Alcaligenes eutrophus A5 and of DDE by biphenyl grown cells of Psudomonas acidovorans M3GY occur via pathways similar to those for biphenyl degradation. Under anaerobic conditions, DDE was reductively dechlorinated to DDMU [1-chloro-2,2-bis-(p-chlorophenyl)ethene] in marine sediment slurries(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: DDE was detected in finfish from Maryland waters at concns of 0.01-0.33 ug/g (1976), 0.02-0.19 ug/g (1977) 0.03-0.45 ug/g (1978), 0-0.73 ug/g (1979) and 0.002-1.08 ug/g(1980)(1). DDE was detected in perch from Patapsco River, MD at concns of 0.02-0.36 ug/g in the spring of 1976(1). DDE was detected in the skin of chinook salmon caught in 1991 from the Great Lakes at concns 52.6-598.8 ppm(2). From 1964-1969, DDE was detected in 323 out of 830 domestic shellfish (mean 0.02 ppm), 17 out of 167 imported shellfish (mean <0.005 ppm), 1,425 out of 2,150 domestic fish samples (mean 0.49 ppm), and in 186 out of 378 imported fish samples (mean 0.06 ppm)(3). The concn of DDE in 2 species of fish caught in the Mexicali Valley of Baja, CA were 1,723.4 and 3,687 ng/g(4). Average concn of DDE in rainbow smelt collected from 1985-1999 at several sites in Lake Huron, Lake Superior and Lake Michigan, ranged from 132-31.6 ng/g, 29.4-11.9 ng/g, and 116-34.3 ng/g fresh weight, respectively, with the highest concn in 1985, and the lowest in 1999(5). DDE concns in pooled fish samples taken from Spider, Hat and Cat Islands in Wisconsin in 1995 were 0.15, 0.11 and 0.11 ug/g wet weight, respectively(6).

NY, NY: Springer-Verlag (1996) (6) Galarini R et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 68: 230-6 (2002) (7) Bervoets L et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 1492-1505 (2005) (8) Yang Y et al; Chemosphere 62: 381-9 (2006) (9) Malik A et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 78: 335-40 (2007) (10) Guitart R et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 75: 143-8 (2005) (11) Abbassy MS et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 70: 1158-64 (2003)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: The mean concns of DDE in various shellfish from New Zealand were reported as 38-2,216 ng/g(1). The mean concns of DDE in pike and perch caught from Lake Orsjoen, Norway in 1994 ranged from 0.53-3,888 ng/g(2). The mean concns of DDE in 8 species of fish caught from the coastal waters of Greenland ranged from 19-680 ng/g(3). The mean concns of DDE in fish from the Mahala Water reservoir, India ranged from 0.09-10.18 ug/g(4). The avg concn of DDE in fish in several rivers in western Mexico was reported as 8.77 ug/g(5). Shellfish from Catalonia, Spain had DDE levels of 2.4-21.8 ng/g(6). The mean concn of DDE in catfish from Trasimeno and Corbara Lakes in Italy were 131 (range of 82-236) and 155 (range of 39-409) ng/g lipid basis, respectively(6). The mean concns of DDE contaminants in Zebra Mussel from waterbodies in Flanders, Belgium collected in 2001-2002 ranged from 0.51 to 5.7 ng/g wet weight(7). DDE was detected in mollusks collected from 4 different sites in mud flaps along the Yangtze estuary (China) in July 2002 at concns ranging from 3-38.3 ng/g wet weight(8). DDE was detected in crabs from 5 of 9 mud flap sites, with concn ranges of 0.5-24.4 ng/g wet weight(8). DDE was detected in 66.67% of fish muscle samples of the Gotmi River in India from 2004-2005, with a mean concn of 1.04 ng/g, ranging from below the detection limit (0.1 ng/g) to 7.61 ng/g wet weight(9). DDE was detected in 28 brown trout, 17 Eurasian minnows, 16 European eels, and a gudgeon from the Ason basin and Nansa river in Spain in January 2001, with total mean concn for all samples of 25.08 and range of 3.00-2012 ng/g dry weight(10). During 1997-1998, DDE was detected in 100% of polti and catfish samples collected from Lake Manzala, Egypt, at mean, minimum and max concns of, respectively, 20.2, 1.56, and 37.1 ng/g (polti), and 6.24, 1.32, and 30.4 ng/g wet weight (catfish)(11).

In anchovy, striped mullet, tuna, shrimp, mussel from the Mediterranean (1976-1977), mean (ranges): 11.3 (4.9-27.6), 16.5 (1.9-32.3), 11.2 (3.3-28.5), 1.5 (0.5-2.7), 9.0 (8.2-9.5) ppb fresh weight, respectively... In marine animals from the Ligurian Sea (1977-1978): shrimp, mean 4.25 ppb; mussel, mean 5.5 ppb... goby fish collected at the seashore of Keihinjima along Tokyo Bay (Aug 1978): residue level: 29 ppb.

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: Murty, A.S. Toxicity of Pesticides to Fish. Volumes I, II. Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press Inc., 1986., p. V1 84
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: In nature, DDE and not DDD constitutes the major component of the sum of DDT ... /and it has been/ reported /that/ DDE is the principal constituent of the sum of DDT in Great Lakes fish; therefore, uptake through food alone cannot explain the increase in the sum of DDT levels of Great Lakes fish. If the uptake of residues is through water, then given an environment with a stable contaminant situation, the fat in all species should accumulate a given pesticide or chemical approx to the same level, depending on the water solubility and partitioning of that chemical into the lipid phase. Such a situation, if observed in nature, would support the conclusion that accumulation is mainly through water.

logP.References: Sangster J; LOGKOW Databank. Sangster Res. Lab., Montreal Quebec, Canada (1994)

mechanism_of_action.Value: Eight chlorinated hydrocarbons were tested for their ability to compete with (3)H-estradiol-17beta for specific binding proteins in uterine cytoplasm from immature rats. o,p'-DDE (0.14 mmol) competed with (3)H-estradiol-17beta for binding to '8s receptor' in uterine cytoplasm but p,p'-DDE and p,p'-DDT did not compete. o,p'-DDT and o,p'-DDE act as estrogens at high concentrations as measured by their ability to compete with estradiol-17beta for binding to uterine cytoplasmic receptor in the transfer and binding of estradiol in nuclei of uterine cells.

In a strain of ducks sensitive to eggshell-thinning effects of DDE, admin of 40 mg/kg in food for 45 days reduced eggshell index (EI) by 13% & content of calcium in the fluid of the shell gland forming an eggshell by 36%, & raised the calcium content of the shell gland mucosa by 19%, compared with control values. DDE inhibited the translocation (secretion) of calcium between the gland mucosa & the uterine cavity. ATP-dependent binding of calcium to microsomal subfraction (FI) rich in fragments of the plasma membrane was reduced by 16%, whereas that to a subfraction FIII which bound calcium at a very high rate was decreased to 36%. DDE may interfere with the stimulus-secretion mechanism of the eggshell gland in ducks through its effect on calcium binding.

In vitro DDE at 2 to 16 ng/L of an homogenate of the eggshell gland of ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) inhibited the Ca(2+)-Mg(2+)-activated ATPase in a concentration-dependent manner, whereas Mg(2+)-activated ATPase was not affected by these concentrations. Since calcium is transported against a concentration gradient between blood plasma & lumen of the eggshell gland, it is suggested that DDE, by inhibiting the Ca(2+)-Mg(2+)-activated ATPase, decreased the calcium translocation over the eggshell gland mucosa.

mechanism_of_action.References: Matsumura, F. Toxicology of Insecticides. 2nd ed. New York, NY: Plenum Press, 1985., p. 450
mechanism_of_action.Value: As for the mechanism of this eggshell thinning phenomenon, no adequate, or generally accepted, explanation exists. There are many reports that claim inhibition of carbonic anhydrase, generally acknowledged to play an important role in forming eggshells, by DDT, /DDE/ & some other derivatives, but there are just as many that deny this. ... Thus one is left with two alternatives to explain the phenomenon: 1) the carbonic anhydrase in the shell gland of avian species is unusually sensitive to chlorinated hydrocarbon insecticides, or 2) the in vivo inhibition observed is a result of some other effect, such as reduced enzyme production or the production of substances that suppress the activity of the enzyme.

Studies were made on the mechanism by which DDE causes eggshell thinning. Addition of DDE inhibits ATPase activities from freeze-dried duck shell gland mucosa homogenates. In vitro sensitivity to low DDE concentration varied with only Ca-ATPase, Na,K-ATPase inhibited below 3 ppm. In in vivo testing, 40 ppm was fed to laying white peking ducks. This level caused 13% shell thinning in 4 days, 18% in 1-3 mo. Thinning was maximal after approx 1 week and then remained constant. Ca-ATPase activity in whole gland homogenates from these ducks was reduced 24% after 4 days and 31% after 1-3 mo. It is suggested that carbonic anhydrase-ATPase, a sol enzyme known to be involved in eggshell formation, has a minor role in shell thinning caused by DDE in duck shells, while a major role is proposed for Ca-ATPase inhibition by DDE. DDE may inhibit a calcium pump in shell gland mitochondria.

In this study, we determined whether the DDT isomers p,p'-DDT [1,1,1,-trichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane], o,p'-DDT [1,1,1-trichloro-2(p-chlorophenyl)-2-(o-chlorophenyl)ethane], and their metabolites p,p'-DDD [1,1-dichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane], o,p'-DDD [1,1-dichloro-2-(p-chlorophenyl)-2-(o-chlorophenyl)ethane], p,p'-DDE [1,1,-dichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethylene], o,p'-DDE [1,1-dichloro-2-(p-chlorophenyl)-2-(o-chlorophenyl)ethylene], and p,p'-DDA [2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)acetic acid], could bind to and transcriptionally activate the human estrogen receptor (hER). Novel results from competitive binding assays showed that o,p'-DDD, o,p'-DDE, and p,p'-DDT, as well as the established environmental estrogen o,p'-DDT, were able to bind specifically to the hER with approximately 1000-fold weaker affinities for the hER than that of estradiol. In contrast, only o,p'-DDT, but not p,p'-DDT, bound to the rat estrogen receptor. Moreover, two yeast expression-reporter systems, constructed to test if the DDT isomers and metabolites could transcriptionally activate the hER, demonstrated that an o,p'-DDT metabolite could transactivate the hER or LexA-hER fusion protein with just a 140- to 300-fold weaker potency than that of estradiol. The DDT isomers and metabolites that bound the hER in vitro triggered estrogen receptor-mediated transcription of the lacZ reporter gene in the yeast systems. Furthermore, the DDT isomers and metabolites that transactivated the hER elicited an additive response when given together or with estradiol. The DDT isomers and metabolites that triggered transcription of the yeast expression-reporter systems also stimulated two estrogenic endpoints in estrogen-responsive MCF-7 cells: the induction of the progesterone receptor and the down-regulation of the hER. Thus, in MCF-7 cells and in yeast expression-reporter systems, certain DDT isomers and metabolites act directly as agonists and transactivate the hER at concentrations found in human tissues.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Glooschenko WA et al; Pestic Monit J 10: 61-7 (1976) (2) Ohio Valley Water Sanitation Commission; Ohio River Main Stream Assess of 1977 and Future Water Quality Conditions For Inclusion in 1978 State Water Qual Rep to the Administrator, USEPA (1978) (3) Kuntz KW; Toxic Contaminants in the Niagara River 1975-82 Burlington Ontario. Technical Bulletin No 134 (1984) (4) Schacht RA; Pesticides in the Illinois Waters of Lake Michigan USEPA-600/3-74-002 (1974) (5) Staples CA et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 4: 131-42 (1985) (6) Brevik EM et al; Chemosphere 33: 2189-2200 (1996) (7) Albert LA; pp. 1-44 in Rev. Environ Contam Toxicol. Vol. 147. Ware GW, ed. NY, NY: Springer-Verlag (1996) (8) Nyangababo JT et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 75: 960-7 (2005) (9) Xue N et al; Chemosphere 61: 1594-1606 (2005) (10) Bervoets L et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 1492-1505 (2005) (11) Van Metre PC, Mahler BJ; Environ Sci Technol 39: 5567-74 (2005) (12) Garcia-Reyero N et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 1427-35 (2005) (13) Abbassy MS et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 70: 1158-64 (2003)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: DDE was detected in sediment from the upper Great Lakes in 1974 at concns of 2-7 ppb(1). DDE was detected in the 10 rivers and streams from the Ohio River valley in February 1977 at concns of 1.1-4.1 ppb(2). DDE was detected in 92% of the suspended sediment samples from the Niagara River at Niagara-on-the-Lake at an avg concn of avg 23 ppb from 1978-1981(3). DDE was detected in Lake Michigan sediment at concns of 0.06-4.82 ppb in 1970-1971(4). DDE was detected in 628 out of 1,047 sediment samples in the US at a median concn of 0.1 ppb(5). The concn of DDE in sediment from Lake Orsjoen, Norway ranged from 0.0002-14 mg/kg, with the greatest concns observed in the top 2 cm of sediment and the lowest concns observed in the deepest (10-12 cm) sediment(6). DDE was detected in sediment samples of 3 coastal lagoons in the Gulf of Mexico at concns of 0.15-1.78 ug/kg(7). DDE was detected in surface sediments collected in May-June 2004 from Katonga, Simiyu and Nyando wetlands in East Africa, at mean (range) concns of 0.065 (0.060-0.070), 0.870 (0.81-0.93), 0.423 (0.402-0.444) ug/kg, respectively(8). DDE was detected in sediment samples from the Guanting reservoir in Beijing at a mean concn (range) of 854 (726-6400) pg/g(9). The concn of DDE contaminants in sediments from waterbodies in Flanders, Belgium in 2001-2002 ranged from <0.05 to 5.4 ng/g dry weight(10). From 1970 to 2001, sediment samples from 38 lakes across the United States showed the levels of p,p'-DDE were decreasing in about 50% of the lakes, and increasing in none(11). The mean concn of DDE in sediment samples from 83 European mountain lakes was 3800 pg/g(12). DDE was detected in 88% of sediment samples collected during 1997-1998 from Lake Manzala, Egypt, at mean, minimum and max concns of 21.89, 1.5 and 34.5 ng/g dry weight, respectively(13).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: Verschueren, K. Handbook of Environmental Data on Organic Chemicals. Volumes 1-2. 4th ed. John Wiley & Sons. New York, NY. 2001, p. 644
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: North Sea and Norwegian depression: bottom sediments: 62-290 parts per trillion; Hawaii: sediments: 110-11,420 parts per trillion.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Carey AE et al; Pest Monit J 12: 117-36 (1978) (2) Wiersma GB et al; Pest Monit Journal 6: 126-9 (1972) (3) Kumari B et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 57: 787-93 (1996) (4) Carey AE et al; Pestic Monit J 12: 117-36 (1978) (5) Frank R et al; Can J Soil Sci 56: 463-84 (1976) (6) Tao S et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 2494-9 (2005) (7) Borghini F et al; Chemosphere 58: 271-8 (2005)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOILS: DDE was detected in soil samples from 5 US cities in 1971 at concns of 0.01-7.86 ppm(1). DDE was detected in soil samples from 8 US cities at avg concns of 0.11-52.73 ppm(2). DDE was detected in soils from India at concns of 0.020-0.024 ug/g in 1992-1994(3). p,p'-DDE and o,p'-DDE were detected in soils from 37 states around the US at concns of 0.01-7.16 and 0.01-0.09 ppm, respectively in 1971(4). DDE was detected in soil samples in Ontario, Canada apple orchards from 1972-75 at the following concns: 0.78-33.3 ppm (0-15 cm); 0.24-5.5 ppm (15-30 cm)(5). DDE was detected in soil samples in Ontario, Canada sour cherry orchards from 1972-75 at the following concns: 0.02-2.13 ppm 0-15 cm); 0.02-0.90 ppm (15-30 cm)(5). DDE was detected in the Rhizosphere and bulk soils from 2 sites in Tianjin, China in September 2002 at mean concns of 56 and 148 ng/g (bulk soil) and 57 and 75 ng/g (rhizosphere soil)(6). In 1999, 4,4'-DDE was detected in soils from Antarctica at concn ranges of 0.053-0.086 ng/g dry weight(7).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Ding JW, Wu SC; Chemosphere 30: 2259-66 (1995) (2) Ding JW, Wu SC; Wat Sci Technol 35: 139-45 (1997) (3) van den Hoop M et al; Water Air Soil Pollut 110: 57-66 (1999) (4) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: The Koc value of p,p'-DDE in soil from Taichung, Taiwan was measured as 26,300(1) and 75,860(2) in soil column batch experiments. The avg log Koc value of DDE in lake sediment was 4.58(3). According to a classification scheme(4), these Koc values suggest that DDE is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC).
